abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts substantial. Among the many lessons
            learned, the following are highlighted. Building on existing
            community, and government structures and processes, made it
            feasible to complement explicit measures, and ensure that
            the institutions function in an effective, inclusive, and
            particular manner. However, clear mechanisms and incentives,
            need to be established up-front to facilitate the
            achievement of the less visible objectives of institutional
            development, and sustainability, i.e., the trade-offs
            between the physical, and more qualitative output targets,
            need to be confronted in the project design, and the
            hierarchy of objectives be defined, and established early
            on. It is emphasized that community-based projects can
            contribute to Eritrea's broader efforts to decentralize
            the provision of public goods, and services to local
            governments, in a way that also helps local governments
            fight poverty, through continuous training and capacity
            building activities. Nonetheless, development impacts could
            be further maximized, by integrating interventions to
            complementary inputs, that is for example, health clinics
            could have yielded optimal outcomes, had design and
            implementation of investments been integrated, and better
            coordinated. But is fair to say that, despite initial
            shortcomings, the commitment, continuity, and pragmatic
            approach of the Eritrea Community Development Fund staff,
            were contributing factors to bridge differences, and enhance effectiveness.
